questions.question: Let P(x)=x^3-3x+1 with roots r,s,t. Compute r^5+s^5+t^5.
questions.solution_outline: Use the recurrence x^3=3x-1 to express x^5=3x^3- x^2 = 3(3x-1) - x^2 = 9x - 3 - x^2. Sum over roots and apply Newton sums with a2=0,a1=-3,a0=1, or build p2,p3,p5.

questions.question: For a,b,c>0 with a+b+c=1, prove sum a^2/(b+c) ≥ 1/2 + sum a^2.
questions.solution_outline: Apply Titu's Lemma: sum a^2/(b+c) ≥ (a+b+c)^2/(2(a+b+c))=1/2, then refine via (a^2/(b+c) - a^2/2) ≥ a^2 - ab - ac.

questions.question: Find all n≥1 such that 3^n+1 is divisible by 2n+1.
questions.solution_outline: Use order arguments mod (2n+1); if an odd divisor p|2n+1 divides 3^n+1 then ord_p(3) | 2n and not | n, so ord=2. Force p=2? Check small n; contradictions via LTE show only n=1 works.

questions.question: Find all functions f: Z→Z with f(x+y)+f(x−y)=2f(x)+2f(y).
questions.answer: f(n)=an^2 for an integer constant a
questions.solution_outline: Set y=0 to get f(0)=0; set x=y to get f(2x)=4f(x); try polynomial ansatz, check quadratic works and linear fails.
